data.title: PrairieSky Royalty (TSX:PSK) Valuation Check After CEO’s Recent Insider Share Purchase

data.title: A Look At Cogent Biosciences (COGT) Valuation After A Strong One Year Shareholder Return
data.description:
Advertisement

Stock performance snapshot and business context

Cogent Biosciences (COGT) has recently seen mixed share performance, with a 1.5% decline over the past day, a 4.0% gain over the past week, a 1.3% rise over the past month, and a 3.4% decline over the past 3 months.

Year to date, the stock is up 11.8%, and the reported 1 year total return is 415.9%, with a 3 year total return of 187.9% and a 5 year total return of 389.9%.

The company is a clinical stage biotechnology business focused on precision therapies for genetically defined diseases, with multiple product candidates in clinical trials targeting specific mutations in systemic mastocytosis, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and other solid tumor indications.

Cogent Biosciences reports revenue of US$0.0 and a net loss of US$328.937 million, which is typical for many early stage biotech firms that are still investing heavily in research and development.

See our latest analysis for Cogent Biosciences.

At a share price of US$38.85, Cogent Biosciences has seen short term share price momentum soften recently, while the very large 1 year total shareholder return suggests earlier bullish sentiment around its clinical pipeline and perceived risk profile.

If Cogent’s biotech story has your attention, it can be useful to compare it with other early stage healthcare names using our screener of 27 healthcare AI stocks as potential next ideas to research.

With the shares at about US$38.85 after a very large 1 year total return, plus a value score of 1 and no current revenue, the key question is whether Cogent is still misunderstood or if the market already prices in future growth.

Preferred Price-to-Book of 11.4x: Is it justified?

At a last close of US$38.85, Cogent Biosciences trades on a P/B of 11.4x, sitting below its peer average but well above the broader US biotech group.

P/B compares the market value of the company to its net assets. It is often used for early stage or loss making businesses where earnings are not yet meaningful. For a clinical stage biotech with no revenue and ongoing losses, a higher P/B can reflect how investors are weighing the company’s pipeline, expected future cash flows, and funding needs against its current balance sheet.

Here, Cogent’s 11.4x P/B is described as good value relative to its peer average of 19.1x. This suggests the market is pricing the stock at a discount to similar names focused on comparable areas. At the same time, the same 11.4x is described as expensive versus the wider US biotechs industry average of 2.7x, meaning investors are currently assigning a much richer valuation than they are to the sector overall.

data.title: Is It Time To Reassess Public Storage (PSA) After Recent Share Price Strength
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Public Storage is fairly priced at around US$307 a share, you are not alone; many investors are trying to work out what they are actually paying for here.
  • The stock has recently posted returns of 0.7% over 7 days, 12.1% over 30 days, 18.8% year to date, 5.4% over 1 year, 13.9% over 3 years, and 61.9% over 5 years, which is prompting fresh questions about both growth potential and risk.
  • Recent coverage has focused on Public Storage as a major US self storage REIT, with investors paying close attention to how the business model fits into the broader real estate sector and demand for storage space. This backdrop helps explain why the market is actively reassessing what a reasonable price might be for the shares today.
  • Right now, our framework gives Public Storage a value score of 4 out of 6, which reflects the number of checks where the stock screens as undervalued. Next, we will walk through the key valuation approaches behind that score, and then finish with a way of looking at valuation that goes a step further.

Public Storage delivered 5.4% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Specialized REITs industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Public Storage Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

The DCF model here takes Public Storage’s adjusted funds from operations, projects them into the future, then discounts those cash flows back to today’s dollars to estimate what the business might be worth right now.

On this basis, Public Storage is modeled using a 2 stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach built on adjusted funds from operations. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $2.78b. Analyst and extrapolated estimates suggest free cash flow reaching around $3.70b by 2030, with a path that moves through projected figures such as $2.81b in 2026 and $3.46b in 2029, all in US dollars.

After discounting these projected cash flows, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $462.30 per share. Compared with the current share price of around $307, this implies a 33.6% discount, which indicates that the shares screen as undervalued under this particular set of assumptions.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Public Storage is undervalued by 33.6%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 46 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Public Storage.

Approach 2: Public Storage Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like Public Storage, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to see what investors are paying for each dollar of earnings. It captures both what the business is earning today and how the market is weighing its prospects and risks.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually line up with a lower, more cautious multiple. The question is not whether a P/E is high or low in isolation, but whether it makes sense given the company’s profile.

Public Storage currently trades on a P/E of 33.99x. That sits above the Specialized REITs industry average of 15.86x, and below the peer group average of 41.55x. Simply Wall St’s Fair Ratio for Public Storage is 34.36x, which is its proprietary estimate of a suitable P/E given the company’s earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and key risks. This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple peer or industry comparison because it tries to account for the specific mix of growth, risk and profitability that is unique to Public Storage.

With the current P/E of 33.99x very close to the Fair Ratio of 34.36x, the shares screen as ABOUT RIGHT on this metric.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 19 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Public Storage Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation. Narratives let you turn your view of Public Storage into a clear story that links its business outlook to a financial forecast, then to a fair value, all inside Simply Wall St’s Community page where millions of investors share their assumptions. You can compare a more upbeat view that leans toward the higher US$350 price target with a more cautious view closer to US$287, see how each Narrative’s fair value stacks up against today’s share price, and watch those fair values update automatically as new earnings, guidance or news come through. This can give you a practical framework to decide whether the current price lines up with your own expectations.

A Discounted Cash Flow model takes projected future cash flows, then discounts them back to today to estimate what the business might be worth now. It is essentially asking what those future dollars are worth in today’s terms.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for USA Rare Earth.

Approach 2: USA Rare Earth Price vs Book

For companies where book value is a meaningful anchor, the P/B ratio is a useful way to see how much investors are paying for each dollar of net assets. It is especially common in capital intensive sectors where tangible assets matter.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk tend to support a higher P/B, while slower growth or higher risk usually justify a lower multiple. That is why it helps to look at a company’s P/B next to its sector and peers, rather than in isolation.

USA Rare Earth currently trades on a P/B ratio of 68.02x. This sits well above the Metals and Mining industry average P/B of 2.66x and above the peer group average of 8.63x. Simply Wall St also uses a “Fair Ratio”, which is a proprietary estimate of what the P/B should be after considering factors such as earnings growth, profit margins, the company’s risks, its industry and its market cap. This Fair Ratio can give you a more tailored anchor than a simple peer or industry comparison, because it adjusts for those company specific features.

On this framework, USA Rare Earth’s current P/B of 68.02x is higher than the Fair Ratio assessment would typically support.

Result: OVERVALUED

P/B ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 19 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your USA Rare Earth Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation, so let us introduce you to Narratives. These are simply your story about a company linked directly to your assumptions for future revenue, earnings, margins and fair value.

On Simply Wall St, Narratives sit in the Community page and let you connect USA Rare Earth’s business story to a clear financial forecast, then to a fair value that you can compare with today’s price to help you decide whether it feels more like a buy, a hold or a sell for you.

Because Narratives on the platform are updated as new information comes in, such as news or earnings, they stay aligned with the latest data without you needing to rebuild your thinking from scratch every time something changes.

For example, one Narrative on USA Rare Earth might see a relatively high fair value based on optimistic assumptions about future cash flows and margins. Another Narrative might point to a much lower fair value because its author expects more modest revenue and profitability.
